conclusion: We have two parallel rails connected to lamps L₁ (3V, 3W) and L₂ (6V, 6W). A rod with resistance r = 1Ω moves at constant speed v across the rails in a magnetic field B = 1T. The distance between rails is l = 0.6m. We're told L₁ lights up normally, and need to find the actual power P₂ of lamp L₂.
Using P = V²/R, we get R₁ = V₁²/P₁ = 3²/3 = 9/3 = 3Ω

premise: When the rod moves in the magnetic field, it generates an EMF
conclusion: ε = Blv, where B = 1T, l = 0.6m, and v is the speed we need to determine
The circuit consists of EMF source (the moving rod): ε = Blv, Resistances: R₁ = 3Ω, R₂ = 6Ω, r = 1Ω (the rod)
The total resistance is: R_total = R₁ + R₂ + r = 3 + 6 + 1 = 10Ω
The current in the circuit will be: I = ε/R_total = Blv/10

premise: Since L₁ lights up normally, the voltage across it must be 3V

conclusion: The voltage across L₂ is: V₂(actual) = IR₂ = 1 × 6 = 6V
The actual power of L₂ is: P₂ = V₂(actual)²/R₂ = 6²/6 = 36/6 = 6W
